title: Pluralistic Ignorance and Alcohol Use on Campus: Some Consequences of Misperceiving the Social Norm

steps: Participants rated their own comfort or attitude toward campus alcohol habits or specific policies (e.g., keg ban).
Participants estimated the comfort or attitude of the average undergraduate student.
In Study 1, participants estimated the interquartile range of the student body's attitudes by bracketing values between which 50% of students fall.
In Study 2, participants also rated the comfort level of their friends.
In Study 2, the order of questions (self first vs. average student first) was manipulated.
In Study 4, participants indicated their willingness to take social action (collecting signatures, spending time discussing protests).
In Study 4, participants indicated their connection to the university (expected reunion attendance, likelihood of donating money).
